children.text: Discussion

Engage in oral exchanges about a topic with peers and adults (e.g., talks with teacher about what she saw at the grocery store after a class visit to the grocery store; after discussing who will play the waiter and who will be the customer at the restaurant, asks, "What would you like to eat?" Other child answers, "I'd like a hamburger, please.").

Initiate and/or extend conversations with peers and adults, using multiple exchanges (e.g., talks with a friend, asking questions about what happened and what the friend did, and shares own ideas. Talks with teacher about a trip to the fire station and asks whether he/she will be able to go again.).
Follow agreed-upon rules for discussion, including raising one's hand, listening politely to the ideas of others, waiting one's turn, and speaking one at a time.
Follow agreed-upon rules for discussion, including raising one's hand, waiting one's turn, speaking one at a time, and listening politely to the ideas of others.
Follow agreed-upon rules for discussion, including raising one's hand, waiting one's turn, speaking one at a time, listening politely to the ideas of others, and gaining the floor in respectful ways.
Follow agreed-upon rules for class discussion and carry out assigned roles in selfrun small group discussions, including posing relevant questions and building on the ideas of others.

Follow agreed-upon rules for class discussion and carry out assigned roles in selfrun small group discussions, including posing relevant questions, building on the ideas of others, and contributing information or ideas.

Apply understanding of agreed-upon rules and individual roles to make decisions, including eliciting and considering suggestions from each group member and defining individuals' roles and responsibilities.

Apply understanding of agreed-upon rules and individual roles to make decisions, including eliciting and considering suggestions from each group member, defining individuals' roles and responsibilities, and coming to consensus.
Know and apply rules for formal and informal discussions, including planning agendas, setting time limits for speakers, and taking votes on key issues.

Identify techniques to improve productivity of group discussions, including setting clear goals, understanding the purpose of the team project and the ground rules for decisionmaking, and setting deadlines.

Implement techniques to improve productivity of group discussions, including setting clear goals, understanding the purpose of the team project and the ground rules for decisionmaking, and setting deadlines.

Participate productively in self-directed teams for a particular purpose, including posing relevant questions; extracting essential information from others' input, building on the ideas of others, and contributing relevant information or ideas in group discussions; and summarizing orally, in a coherent and organized way, information and ideas learned.

Participate productively in self-directed teams for a particular purpose, including ensuring a hearing for a range of positions, tolerating ambiguity and a lack of consensus when necessary, consulting texts as sources of ideas, acknowledging the ideas and contributions of individuals in the group, and completing the task in a timely fashion.
Evaluate how well participants engage in discussions, and participate in a formal and an informal meeting or on a television news discussion program.
Questioning, Listening, and Contributing

Demonstrate understanding of explanations (e.g., talks about how the sun melts a snowman after a class experiment with snow and water. Takes blocks down one at a time from tower after teacher reminds children of safety rules.).
Listen to stories attentively (e.g., asks questions related to the story's subject: "Where did Ms. Flossy get all those hats?" Laughs at funny parts of a story.).

Ask questions to get information, ask for help, clarify something that is not understood (e.g., asks, "Why is the man wearing a uniform?" Looking at a friend's drawing, asks, "How come her hair is green?").

Answer questions with increasing complexity (e.g., responds, "In my backpack" when asked, "Where's your book?" Says, "I'd use rocks so the wolf can't blow it down" when teacher asks what kind of house he would build.).
Follow directions of two or more steps.
Share information, opinions, and questions, speaking audibly in coherent sentences.
Describe people, places, things, location, size, color, shape, and action.
Use appropriate tone and inflection to express ideas, feelings, and needs.
Follow directions that involve one- or two-step related sequences of action.
Listen attentively by facing the speaker.
Describe familiar objects, people, and events and their attributes with specific words and phrases.
Give, restate, and follow oral directions that involve two unrelated sequences of action.
Know and practice appropriate listening behavior.
Provide descriptions with careful attention to sensory detail (e.g., how something smells, feels, sounds, looks).
Ask questions to clarify confusion about a topic.
Give, restate, and follow oral directions that involve a series of unrelated sequences of action.
Retell and paraphrase information shared orally by others.
Respond to questions with appropriate elaboration and detail (e.g., explain, amplify, expand).
Identify the musical elements of literary language (e.g., rhythm, rhymes, pace, tone, tempo, repeated sounds, or instances of onomatopoeia).
Summarize major ideas and supporting evidence presented in spoken messages and formal presentation.
Ask thoughtful questions and respond to relevant questions with appropriate elaboration in oral settings.
Identify how language use (sayings, slang, idioms, usages) reflects regions and cultures.
Interpret speakers' messages (both verbal and nonverbal), purposes, and perspectives.
Make inferences and draw conclusions based on the ideas presented in an oral report.
Ask questions that clarify information not already discussed.
Relate the speaker's verbal communication (e.g., word choice, pitch, feeling, tone) and nonverbal messages/"body language" (e.g., posture, gestures).
Identify the tone, mood, and emotion conveyed in oral communication.
Restate and execute multistep oral instructions and directions.
Ask probing questions to elicit information, including questions about the evidence that supports the speaker's claims and conclusions.
Determine the speaker's attitude or point of view toward the subject.
Distinguish between a summary of and an advocacy of a position in an oral presentation.
Explain different ways to read a poem aloud for different effects on the listener.
Paraphrase the speaker's purpose and point of view and ask relevant questions concerning a speaker's content, delivery, and purpose.
Respond to persuasive messages with questions, challenges, or affirmations.
Summarize in a coherent and organized way the information and ideas learned from a focused discussion.
Identify the controlling idea or specific purpose of a speech and determine the essential elements that elaborate it.
Assess how word choice and delivery establish the tone and emotion of the speech and affect the audience.
Formulate judgments about the ideas under discussion and support those judgments with convincing evidence.
Analyze the ways in which the style and structure of a speech support or frustrate its meaning or purpose.
Critique the impact of diction and syntax used by speakers on purpose and audience.
Analyze differences in responses to focused group discussion in an organized and systematic way.
Evaluate the clarity, quality, effectiveness and overall coherence of a speaker's key points, arguments, evidence, organization of ideas, delivery, diction, and syntax.
Analyze types of arguments used by the speaker, including argument by causation, analogy, authority, emotion, and logic.
Distinguish between inductive and deductive reasoning in an argument.
Identify logical fallacies present in oral addresses (e.g., attack ad hominem, false causality, red herring, overgeneralization, bandwagoning).
Analyze the four basic types of persuasive speeches (propositions of fact, value, problem, or policy) and their use of patterns of organization, persuasive language, reasoning, and proofs.

Recognize and use elements of classical speech form (introduction, first and second transitions, body, and conclusion), formulating sound, rational arguments and applying the art of persuasion and debate.
Oral Presentation
Retell story events in sequence (e.g., uses flannel board pieces to retell the story of The Runaway Rice Cake in her own words.).
Relate an experience or story in logical sequence.
Recite poems, rhymes, and songs, and retell stories in a logical sequence.
Retell stories using standard grammar rules, sequencing story events by answering who, what, where, when, how, and why questions.
Recite poems, rhymes, songs, and stories, speaking clearly at an understandable pace.
Relate an important event in life or describe personal interests, maintaining focus on the topic and speaking clearly at an understandable pace.
Recite poems, rhymes, songs, and stories using appropriate tempo, volume, and phrasing.
Give presentations about experiences or interests that have a recognizable organization using appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.
Recite prose and poetry aloud with fluency, rhythm, pace, and appropriate intonation and vocal patterns to emphasize key ideas and areas of importance expressed by the author.
Use teacher- and student-generated assessment criteria to prepare and assess presentations.
Use teacher-generated rubric (scoring guide) to prepare the presentations described in this section.
Express opinion of a political speech in an organized way, with supporting detail, good eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.
Make informal presentations that have a recognizable organization (e.g., sequencing, summarizing), using clear enunciation and adequate volume.
Use teacher- and student-generated assessment criteria to prepare and assess presentations.
Review and refine teacher-generated rubric (scoring guide) to prepare and assess presentations described in this section.
Organize ideas into presentations that provide a beginning, middle, and end, using various delivery strategies (volume, pitch, phrasing, pace, gestures) to communicate meaning.
Recite poems (four or more stanzas), sections of speeches, or dramatic soliloquies using clear diction, tempo, volume, and phrasing.
Create a rubric (scoring guide) based on categories generated by the teacher and students (content, presentation style) to prepare and assess the presentations listed in this section.
Give oral presentations with focus, organization, and point of view, matching purpose, message, occasion, voice modulation, and nonverbal elements to the audience.
Create a rubric (scoring guide) based on categories generated by the teacher and students (content, organization, presentation style) to prepare and assess the presentations listed in this section.

Present critiques of literary works, films, or dramatic productions using various techniques for effective presentations, and matching the message with voice modulation, inflection, tempo, enunciation, and expression.

Create a rubric (scoring guide) based on categories generated by the teacher and students (content, organization, presentation style, vocabulary) to prepare and assess the presentations listed in this section.
Present persuasive speeches that use appropriate techniques such as descriptions, anecdotes, case studies, analogies, and illustrations to advocate a position.
Distinguish and produce formal and informal language appropriate to the audience and purpose, including knowing how to use language for dramatic effect.

Create a rubric (scoring guide) based on categories generated by the teacher and students (content, organization, presentation style, vocabulary) to prepare, improve, and assess the presentations listed in this section.

Deliver focused oral presentations that use details, examples, or anecdotes to explain or clarify information or a point of view, employing proper eye contact, speaking rate, volume, enunciation, inflection, and gestures to communicate ideas effectively.

Create a rubric (scoring guide) based on categories generated by the teacher and students (content, organization, presentation style, vocabulary) to prepare, improve, and assess the presentations listed in this section.
Analyze effective speeches (e.g., Martin Luther King's "I Have a Dream" address) and deliver a speech with some of the same rhetorical features.

Give formal and informal talks, using appropriate level of formality for audience and purpose, as well as rhetorical devices (e.g., alliteration, analogy, expletive, hyperbole, metaphor, parallelism, simile).

Create a rubric (scoring guide) based on categories generated by the teacher and students (content, organization, presentation style, vocabulary) to prepare, improve, and assess the presentations listed in this section.

Deliver formal presentations that exhibit a logical structure appropriate to the audience, context, and purpose; communicate group-related ideas; maintain a consistent focus, including smooth transitions; and support judgments through the effective and accurate use of evidence and well-chosen details.

Create a rubric (scoring guide) based on categories generated by the teacher and students (content, organization, presentation style, vocabulary) to prepare, improve, and assess the presentations listed in this section.

Formulate and deliver sound, rational arguments that are well supported with evidence appropriate to the audience and context, and use clear enunciation and appropriate organization, gestures, tone, and vocabulary.
Vocabulary and Concept Development
Use words to describe concrete objects, actions, and feelings (e.g., says, "She's upset" when she sees a child crying; rubs stomach and says, "My lunch is awesome.").

Integrate new vocabulary into conversations with peers and adults (e.g., uses the word hurricane after teacher explains that a big wind and rain storm is called a hurricane; calls her block structure enormous after hearing the word read aloud from a book.).
Add descriptive words to basic subject-verb-object sentences (e.g., notes, "We have pretty yellow flowers in the garden."; says, "My baby brother is very cranky.").
Ask questions to acquire new vocabulary (e.g., points to a front-end loader and says, "Look. What's that?"; asks, "What's a waterspout?" after singing The Itsy-Bitsy Spider.).
Determine what words mean from how they are used in a sentence, either heard or read.
Sort common objects into basic categories (e.g., colors, shapes, foods).
Describe common objects and events in both general and specific language.
Use language to express spatial (up, down) and temporal (before, after) relationships.
Identify base words (look) and their inflectional forms (e.g., looks, looked, looking).
Classify common words into conceptual categories (e.g., animals, foods, opposites).
Recognize that some words, called compound words, are made up of two short words (e.g., sailboat, football, popcorn).
Determine meanings of words by using a beginning dictionary.
Identify and use prefixes and suffixes (e.g., un-, re-, -ful, -ly) to determine the meaning of words.
Identify common antonyms and synonyms.
Determine the meaning of compound words using knowledge of the meaning of individual words (e.g., lunchtime, daydream, everyday).
Identify the relevant meaning for a word with multiple meanings using its context (saw/saw).
Determine meanings and uses of words (parts of speech) by using a beginning dictionary (i.e., nouns, verbs, adjectives, etc.).
Identify the meaning of common prefixes and suffixes (e.g., un-, re-, in-, dis-, -ful, -ly, -less), and know how they change the meaning of roots (e.g., happy/unhappy, tell/retell).
Identify roots of words (e.g., "graph" is a common root in autograph, photograph, biography).
Identify playful uses of language (e.g., tongue twisters, riddles).
Recognize that some words and phrases have both a literal and nonliteral meaning (e.g., take steps).
Use context of the sentence to determine the intended meaning of an unknown word or a word with multiple meanings (e.g., hatch, arm, boot).
Determine meanings of words and alternate word choices using intermediate-level dictionaries and thesauri.
Determine the effect of affixes on roots (e.g., the effect of "un" on roots such as "happy" or "common" to make the words "unhappy" or "uncommon").

Use knowledge of morphology or the analysis of word roots and affixes to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words (e.g., meaning of Greek root "graph" to understand the meaning of the words telegraph, photograph, and autograph).
Identify and use playful language such as puns, jokes, and palindromes.
Identify the meaning of figurative language and phrases (e.g., "last straw," "cold feet," "I'm in hot water.").
Recognize and use words with multiple meanings (e.g., sentence, school, hard) and determine which meaning is intended from the context of the sentence.
Determine meanings and other features of words (e.g., pronunciation, syllabication, parts of speech) using intermediate-level dictionaries and thesauri.
Identify the meaning of common Greek and Latin roots and affixes to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words.
Identify and apply the meanings of the terms antonym, synonym, and homophone.
Determine the meaning of unfamiliar words in context using definitions and examples stated in the text.
Identify meanings, pronunciations, alternate word choices, correct spellings, and parts of speech of words using dictionaries and thesauri (printed and electronic).

Determine the meaning of unfamiliar words using knowledge of English language structure, Greek and Latin roots (e.g., annus, aqua), suffixes (e.g., -itis, -osis), and prefixes (e.g., multi-, dis-, anti-, hyper-, syn-).
Use such clues as definition, example, and restatement to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words and words with multiple meanings in context.
Determine the meaning of figurative language, including similes, metaphors, personification, and grade-appropriate idioms.
Determine meanings, pronunciations, alternate word choices, correct spellings, and parts of speech of words using dictionaries, glossaries, thesauri, and other resources (printed and electronic).

Use Greek and Latin roots and affixes to determine the meaning of content area vocabulary (e.g., in readings on pioneers of space, determine the meanings of the words astronaut and nautical using knowledge of Greek and Latin roots).
Use such clues as cause and effect and comparison and contrast to identify the meaning of unfamiliar words and words with multiple meanings in context.
Use context to confirm meanings of metaphors, similes, and idiomatic language in prose and poetry.

Determine meanings, pronunciations, alternate word choices, correct spellings, parts of speech, or etymologies of words using dictionaries, glossaries, thesauri, and other resources (printed and electronic).
Know the origins and meanings of common foreign words used in English (e.g., ad infinitum, bon voyage, a la carte, carte blanche, de luxe, pro rate, quid pro quo), and use these words accurately.
Monitor text for unknown words or words with novel meanings, using word, sentence, and paragraph clues to determine meaning.
Understand and explain "shades of meaning" for related words (e.g., annoyed, irritated, aggravated, irked, miffed, peeved, angry, irate, furious, enraged).
Determine meanings, pronunciations, syllabication, synonyms, antonyms, correct spellings, parts of speech, or etymologies of words using dictionaries, glossaries, thesauri, CD-ROMs, and the Internet.

Use Greek, Latin, and Norse mythology; the Bible; and other works often alluded to in American and world literature to understand the meaning of words or phrases (e.g., "narcissistic" from the myth of Narcissus and Echo, or "Tower of Babel" from the Bible).
Determine the meanings of multiple-meaning words by using context.

Determine meanings, pronunciations, contextually appropriate synonyms and antonyms, replacement words and phrases, etymologies, and correct spellings of words using dictionaries, thesauri, histories of language, and books of quotations.
Identify and use idioms, cognates, and the literal and figurative meanings of words in speaking and writing.
Distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words, and interpret the connotative power of words.

Determine meanings, pronunciations, contextually appropriate synonyms and antonyms, replacement words and phrases, etymologies, and correct spellings of words using dictionaries, thesauri, histories of language, and books of quotations.

Apply knowledge of Greek, Latin, or other linguistic roots and affixes to draw inferences about the meaning of specialized vocabulary (e.g., antecedent, antebellum, circumference, millennium, millimeter, amphibian, heterogeneous, perimeter).
Identify the meanings of metaphors (e.g., Scrooge, Madame LaFarge, "house of glass") based on common literary allusions and conceits.
Use general and specialized dictionaries, thesauri, glossaries, or related references as needed.
Trace the etymology of significant terms used in core content areas (e.g., social studies, science).
Use general and specialized dictionaries, thesauri, histories of language, books of quotations, and other related references as needed.
Print Concepts
Treat books with care (e.g., carefully turns the pages of a book and then returns it to the shelf with cover facing out. Tells teacher that a page in the book is ripped and needs fixing.).

Hold books right side up and know that books are read from front to back, top to bottom (e.g., looks at left page and then right page when looking through a book. Turns book right side up when handed to him upside down.).

Understand the concept of title, author, and illustrator (e.g., points to the words Max Found Two Sticks and says, "That's the name of this book." Says, "The illustrator is the person who makes the pictures.").

Know that spoken words can be written and read and written words can be spoken aloud (e.g., asks the teacher to write "I love you" on a card for his father. Looks at menu and asks, "Which word says pancakes?").

Know that print is read from left to right in English and many other languages (e.g., runs finger over text, from left to right and top to bottom, as he pretends to read. Points to beginning of sentence when teacher asks, "Where should I start reading the first line of this poem?").

Use pictures as clues to the text (e.g., says, "I think this book is going to be about a princess because there's a castle picture." Looking at a picture in Stone Soup by John Muth, says, "He's going to put carrots in that pot."). Understand concept of term "The End."
Initiate reading behaviors (e.g., selects a book and talks about the pictures on each page. Looks through a book about trucks with a friend.).
Recognize that print represents spoken language and provides information or entertaining stories.
Hold a book right side up and turn pages in the correct direction and order.
Start at the top left of the printed page; track words from left to right, using return sweep; move from the top to the bottom of the page.
Identify different parts of a book (e.g., front cover, back cover, title page) and the information they provide.
Recognize that spoken words are represented in written language by specific sequences of letters.
Recognize that words are separated by spaces.
Recognize that sentences in print are made up of separate words.
Demonstrate the one-to-one correlation between a spoken word and a printed word.
Identify upper- and lower-case letters.
Understand that spoken words are represented in written English by sequences of letters.
Recognize the distinguishing features of a sentence (e.g., capitalization, ending punctuation).
Identify the author and title of a book, and use a book's table of contents.
Know the order of the letters of the alphabet.
Match oral words to printed words.
Recognize the distinguishing features of a sentence (e.g., capitalization of the first word, internal punctuation, ending punctuation, and quotation marks).
Phonemic Awareness

Identify words that rhyme in songs, nursery rhymes, poems, and stories (e.g., says, "Two and shoe" when teacher asks, "Which words rhyme?" in the second verse of This Old Man. Tells friend that Mack and black rhyme while clapping and singing Miss Mary Mack.).

Produce (make up) rhymes (e.g., supplies a rhyming word for the sentence There's a cat on the ___ (mat). Replaces familiar rhymes with silly ones, such as Humpty Dumpty; Gumpty, Numpty. Hears and identifies individual words in a sentence.

Hear syllables in words (e.g., claps hands three times for syllables in Susannah. Stomps feet rhythmically singing "jam-bo, jam-bo" ["hello" in Swahili]. Hears individual phonemes in words - /c/ /a/ /t/.).

Discriminate sounds as being the same or different (e.g., says, "Mat, sit, and pet all sound the same at the end." Explains, "We have three kids whose names start like mine: Nicholas, Naomi, and Nouri."). Manipulate sounds (e.g. with "cat," changes the /c/ to /b/ and says "bat."). Blend individual phonemes to form words.
Distinguish rhyming words from nonrhyming words spoken aloud (e.g., run, sun versus run, man).
Orally produce rhyming words in response to spoken words (e.g., What rhymes with hat?).
Blend spoken simple onsets and rhymes to form real words (e.g., onset /c/ and rhyme /at/ makes "cat").
Use alliteration to orally produce groups of words that begin with the same initial consonant sound (e.g., baby boy bounces the ball).
Blend two or three spoken syllables to say words.
Blend spoken phonemes to form a single-syllable word (e.g., /m/  /a/  /n/  makes "man").
Distinguish between initial, medial, and final sounds in single-syllable words.

Segment one-syllable words into their phonemes, using manipulatives to mark each phoneme (e.g., dog makes /d/  /o/  /g/ while the student moves a block or tile for each phoneme). Manipulates phonemes (changes /c/ to /b/ in cat to form a new word - bat).
Generate a series of original rhyming words, including consonant blends (e.g., bl, st, tr).
Orally segment a multisyllabic word into its syllables.
Recognize the new spoken word when a specified phoneme is added, changed, or removed (e.g., changes cow to how, pan to an).
Distinguish between long- and short-vowel sounds in orally stated single-syllable words (bit/bite).
Blend spoken phonemes with more than three sounds into one-syllable words, including consonant clusters and all speech sounds, including those represented by digraphs, such as /th/, /sh/, etc.
Segment spoken phonemes contained in one-syllable words of two to five phonemes into individual phonemes (e.g., "splat" = /s/p/l/a/t/ using manipulatives to mark each phoneme).
Blend isolated phonemes to form two-syllable words using vowel digraphs and vowel diphthongs.
Segment spoken phonemes in two-syllable words using manipulatives to mark each phoneme (e.g., "tiger" makes /t/  /i/  /g/  /er/ while student moves one block for each phoneme).
Phonics
Identify 10 or more letters (e.g., sees a stop sign and says, "That's S-T-O-P." Uses the alphabet stamps and names the letters.).
Name letters in own name and in familiar words (e.g., identifies own name and mom and dad in print and names letters. Points to an M and says, "This is for Mommy.").
Find specific letters in words in the environment (e.g., knows that the sign that says Metro begins with a big letter M. Points to Cheerios box and says, "That's C, like in my name.").

Begin to make letter-sound connections (e.g., figures out which word says banana because she knows it starts with b. Points to the letter T on the wall and says, "That's for my To [uncle in Spanish] Csar.").

Use different strategies (known words, knowledge of letters and sounds, patterns in text) to make meaning from print (e.g., anticipates what comes next as she reads Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See? Says, "That word says food. It's for the fish" when picking up the can next to the aquarium.).
Know there is a link between letters and sounds and that written words are composed of letters that represent sounds.
Recognize letter-sound matches by naming and identifying each letter of the alphabet and the sounds they represent in decodable text.
Use letter-sound matches to decode simple words in decodable text.
Recognize that a new word is created when a specific letter is changed, added, or removed.

Decode regularly spelled one- and two-syllable words fluently in decodable text by applying the most common letter-sound correspondences, including the sounds represented by
  • single letters (consonants and vowels)
  • consonant blends (e.g., bl, st, tr)
  • consonant digraphs (e.g., th, sh, ck)
  • vowel digraphs and diphthongs (e.g., ea, ie, ee)
Use knowledge of inflectional endings (e.g., -s, -ed, -ing) to identify base words.
Read common abbreviations (e.g., Wed., Sept.) fluently.
Use knowledge of base words to predict the meaning of compound words (e.g., football, popcorn, daydream).
Read words with common spelling patterns (e.g., -ite, -iate) in decodable text.
Recognize high-frequency words and irregular sight words (e.g., the, have, said, come, give, of).
Generate the sounds from all the letters and letter patterns, including consonant blends and long- and short-vowel patterns (phonograms), to combine those sounds into recognizable words.
Decode phonetically regular multisyllabic real and nonsense words fluently using letter-sound knowledge.
Apply knowledge of basic syllabication rules when reading two- or three-syllable written words (e.g., v/cv = su/per, vc/cv = sup/per).

Apply the most common letter-sound correspondences, including the sounds represented by single letters, consonant blends, consonant digraphs (e.g., ng in sing), and vowel digraphs and diphthongs (e.g., ea, oy).
Recognize regular plurals (e.g., -s, -es, -ies) and irregular plurals (e.g., fly/flies, wife/wives) in context.
Identify the two words that make up a contraction and read common contractions accurately (e.g., haven't, it's, aren't).
Read common abbreviations (e.g., Mr., Mrs., Ave., Rd.) fluently.
Read accurately special vowel spellings and common word endings in decodable text.
Recognize common irregularly spelled words by sight (e.g., have, said, where).
Know and use word families (e.g., -ight, -ought) to decode unknown words.
Apply knowledge of basic syllabication rules when reading four- or five-syllable written words (e.g., "information," "multiplication," "pepperoni") in decodable text.

Apply knowledge of the following common spelling patterns to read words in decodable text that
  • drop the final "e" and add endings such as -ing, -ed, or -able (e.g., use, using, used, usable);
  • have final consonants that need to be doubled when adding an ending (e.g., hop to hopping);
  • require changing the final "y" to "i" (e.g., baby to babies);
  • end in -tion, -sion (e.g., election, vision); and
  • include common prefixes, suffixes, and root words.
Identify the two words that make up regular and irregular contractions (e.g., won't = will not; I'd = I would).
Use knowledge of word order (syntax) and context to confirm decoding.
Fluency
Read aloud grade-appropriate text fluently, accurately, and with comprehension.
Read aloud grade-appropriate text fluently, accurately, and with comprehension.
Read aloud from familiar prose and poetry with fluency and appropriate rhythm, pacing, expression, and intonation relevant to the text.

Read aloud from familiar literary and informational text fluently, accurately, and with comprehension, using appropriate timing, change in voice, and expression. Note: Students will have met the grade K-3 standards by the end of grade 3, although teachers should continue to address the earlier standards as needed and as they apply to more difficult texts.

Read aloud from familiar literary and informational text fluently, accurately, and with comprehension, using appropriate timing, change in voice, and expression.

Note: Students will have met the grade K-3 standards by the end of grade 3, although teachers should continue to address the earlier standards as needed and as they apply to more difficult texts.
Expository Text

Use books and other printed materials to find information (e.g., says "That bus with the 'A' on it goes to my grandma's house." Says, "You have to put the pattern blocks here because the sign says so" when another child asks, "Where do these go?").

Answer questions about stories and other print materials (e.g., responds, "I think he was afraid he would miss his mommy" when asked why Ira took his teddy bear when he went to sleep at his friend's house. Says, "We'll have snack when we come inside" in response to another child's question about the written schedule.).
Identify the purpose for reading informational text.
Retell important facts from a text heard or read.
Make predictions about the content of text using prior knowledge and text features (title, captions, illustrations).
Identify the topic of text heard or read.
Respond appropriately to questions based on facts in text heard or read.
Make predictions about the content using text features (e.g., title, table of contents, headings, bold print).
Identify the purpose and restate important facts from a text heard or read.
Answer questions (e.g., who, what, where, when, why, how) about text heard or read.
Make predictions about the content using text features (e.g., title, table of contents, headings, captions, key words) and explain why the predictions were or were not confirmed.
Identify the purpose or main point and supporting details in text.
Identify the facts given in a text.
Distinguish cause from effect.
Identify and use knowledge of common textual features to make predictions about content (e.g., title, headings, table of contents, glossary, captions).
Form questions about text and locate facts in response to those questions.
Identify the purpose and main points of a text and summarize its supporting details.
Distinguish fact from opinion.
Identify cause-and-effect relationships (stated and implied).
Identify and use knowledge of common textual features (e.g., paragraphs, topic sentences, concluding sentences, glossary).
Ask questions and support answers by connecting prior knowledge with literal and inferential information found in texts.
Identify the author's purpose and summarize the critical details of expository text, maintaining chronological or logical order.
Distinguish fact from opinion in expository text, providing supporting evidence from text.
Compare (and contrast) the author's purpose in informational selections on the same topic.
Identify and use knowledge of common textual features (e.g., title, headings, key words, captions, paragraphs, topic sentences, table of contents, index, glossary).
Identify common organizational structures such as chronological order and cause and effect.
Identify and analyze the author's stated purpose, main ideas, supporting ideas, and supporting evidence.
Identify and use knowledge of common textual features (paragraphs, topic sentences, concluding sentences, glossary, index, and bibliography).
Identify and use organizational structures in text, including chronological order, comparison and contrast, cause and effect, logical order, and classification schemes.
Identify the author's purpose(s) in a text when it is not stated.
Identify and use knowledge of common textual features (paragraphs, topic sentences, concluding sentences, glossary, index, bibliography, footnotes, introduction, conclusion).
Apply knowledge of organizational structures of text to aid comprehension, including chronological order, comparison and contrast, cause and effect, logical order, and classification schemes.
Compare (and contrast) the central ideas, problems, or situations from readings on a specific topic selected to reflect a range of viewpoints.
Explain how an author uses word choice and organization of text to achieve his purposes.
Distinguish between the concept of theme in a literary work and the author's explicit or implicit purpose in an expository text.
Analyze the main or controlling idea in passages or paragraphs.
Compare (and contrast) original text to a summary for accuracy of the main ideas, inclusion of critical details, and the extent to which it conveys the underlying meaning of the original text.
Read a challenging passage and respond to clarifying questions concerning essential textual elements of expository text (e.g., why, who, what, where, when, how, what if).
Explain how one excerpt relates and contributes to the reading selection (e.g., how a sentence relates to a paragraph, how a paragraph relates to a selection).
Support conclusions drawn from ideas and concepts in informational and technical passages.
Evaluate the appropriateness of an author's word choice for an intended audience.
Summarize the purpose and main ideas in passages; distinguish between a summary and a critique.
Explain the author's stated or implied purpose(s) for writing expository text.
Describe the controlling idea or specific purpose of passages and paragraphs and determine the essential elements that elaborate it.

Analyze implied or subtly stated interrelationships between and among ideas and concepts within expository text, such as cause and effect, problem and solution, comparison and contrast, and proposition and support.
Make relevant inferences by synthesizing concepts and ideas from a single reading selection.
Locate and interpret minor or subtly stated details in passages and discern which ideas or arguments they support.
Make relevant inferences, comparisons, and generalizations that reveal a feeling for the subtleties in relationships between and among the ideas in passages.
Critique the consistency and clarity of the text's (author's) purposes.
Distinguish among different kinds of evidence used to support conclusions (e.g., logical, empirical, anecdotal).
Describe how sentence variety affects the overall effectiveness of an expository essay.
Relate primary source documents (nonliterary) to the historical events of their time.
Infer subtly stated or implied cause-and-effect relationships and analyze the essential elements that elaborate them.
Discern which details, although they may appear in different sections throughout a passage, support important points in more challenging passages.
Critique the effectiveness of the organizational pattern (e.g., logic, focus, consistency, coherence, visual appeal) of text.
Determine the accuracy and truthfulness of one source of information by examining evidence offered in the material itself and by comparing the evidence with information from multiple sources.

Compare (and contrast) readings on the same topic by explaining how authors reach the same or different conclusions based on differences in evidence, reasoning, assumptions, purposes, beliefs, or biases.
Document and Procedural Text
Follow a two- or three-step set of directions (e.g., recipes, center directions, classroom procedures, science experiments) using picture clues.
State the meaning of specific signs (e.g., traffic, safety, warning signs).
Follow a set of written multistep directions with picture cues to assist.
State the meaning of specific signs, graphics, and symbols (e.g., computer icons, map features, simple charts and graphs).
Follow a set of written multistep directions.
Identify and use knowledge of common graphic features (illustrations, type, size).
Locate specific information in graphic representations (e.g., charts, maps, diagrams, illustrations, tables, timelines) of text.
Use information from text and text features to determine the sequence of activities needed to carry out a procedure.
Interpret information in graphic representations (e.g., charts, maps, diagrams, illustrations, tables, timelines) of text.
Locate specific information from text (e.g., letters, memos, directories, menus, schedules, pamphlets, search engines, signs, manuals, instructions, recipes, labels, forms).
Interpret details from text to complete a task, solve a problem, or perform procedures.
Identify the components (e.g., directions, legend, illustrations, diagram, sequence, boldface print, headings) of document and procedural text.
Respond appropriately to a set of instructions and complete a task.
Determine what information (e.g., steps in directions, legend, supplies needed, illustrations, diagram, sequence) is missing or extraneous in document and procedural text.
Evaluate the adequacy of details and facts to achieve a specific purpose.

Describe the objective(s) of document and procedural text (e.g., warranties, product information, manuals, consumer publications) and analyze a document for its "user friendliness" and graphic design.
Synthesize information from multiple sources (e.g., maps, illustrations, schematic diagrams, manuals, product information, consumer publications) to draw conclusions about the ideas presented.
Analyze the presentation of information.
Analyze the structures of document and procedural text (e.g., their format, graphics, and headers) to determine how authors use these features and textual elements to achieve their purposes.
Analyze the graphic representations within technical research documents for their clarity and relevance.

Analyze how the patterns of organization, hierarchic structures, repetition of key ideas, syntax, and word choice influence the clarity and understandability of document and procedural text (e.g., manuals, product support material, contracts, applications).
Evaluate the logic within document and procedural text such as manuals, product support material, and contracts.
Argument and Persuasive Text
Identify what the author is arguing or trying to persuade the reader to think or do.
Determine an author's position (i.e., what the author is arguing), providing supporting evidence from the text.

Identify the effect of persuasive strategies and rhetorical techniques (e.g., peer pressure, emotional appeal, exaggeration, repetition) that the author uses to influence readers' thinking or behavior.
Recognize arguments for and against an issue.
Describe the facts and evidence used to support an argument.
Identify ways to detect bias in persuasive text.
Distinguish a stereotype from a generalization.
Recognize organizational structures and arguments for and against an issue.
Distinguish facts from opinions in selections such as editorials, newspaper articles, essays, reviews, and critiques, providing supporting evidence from the text.
Compare and contrast readings on the same topic and explain how authors reach different conclusions, beginning with the author's stated position.
Describe the central argument and its elements (e.g., argument by cause and effect, analogy, authority, emotion, or logic) in a contemporary political speech.
Identify figurative language and rhetorical structures (parallel structure, quotations, examples, exaggeration, emotional appeal) used to engage the audience.
Distinguish supported inferences from unsupported inferences in contemporary political speeches, editorials, or newspaper articles.
Analyze the logic and use of evidence in an author's argument.

Describe how rhetorical techniques (e.g., repetition, sentence variety, understatement, overstatement, irony, sarcasm) contribute to the effects of persuasive text, given the audience, purpose, and occasion.
Identify an author's implicit and stated assumptions about an issue based on evidence in the selection.

Recognize common fallacies such as the appeal to pity, the personal attack, double-speak, the appeal to common opinion, and the false dichotomy; understand why these fallacies do not prove the point being argued.
Evaluate the arguments an author uses in a speech or op-ed to refute opposing or counterarguments and address reader or listener concerns.
Recognize the use or abuse of ambiguity, contradiction, paradox, irony, incongruities, overstatement, and understatement in text, and explain their effect on the reader.
Evaluate the effectiveness of the logic and use of evidence in an author's argument.
Evaluate the merits of an argument, action, or policy by citing evidence offered in the material itself and by comparing the evidence with information available in other sources.
Evaluate the effectiveness of an author's use of rhetorical devices in a persuasive argument.
Identify unexamined presumptions in an argument  that is, determine if the presumptions are false, whether the argument fails or not.
Evaluate persuasive sources for adherence to ethics (e.g., Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "Letter from Birmingham Jail").
Understanding Text

Retell story events in sequence (e.g., uses flannel board pieces to retell the story of The Runaway Rice Cake in her own words. Uses props on a shelf in the library area to act out and retell The River That Gave Gifts in his own words after hearing the teacher tell the story using props.).

Answer questions about stories and other print materials (e.g., responds, "I think he was afraid he would miss his mommy" when asked why Ira took his teddy bear when he went to sleep at his friend's house. Says, "We'll have snack when we come inside" in response to another child's question about the written schedule.).

Question, compare, and predict story events (e.g., asks, "Why can't old people remember things?" while listening to Wilfrid Gordon McDonald Partridge read aloud. After the teacher asks, "Which book do you like better, The Cat In The Hat or The Cat In The Hat Comes Back, and why?" says, "The Cat In The Hat Comes Back 'cause the little cats are silly!").

Relate book experiences to own life (e.g., compares his own feelings about a new baby in his house to Peter's feelings when the teacher reads Peter's Chair. Looks at book about dogs and says, "I have a dog just like this one. His name is Max.").
Make predictions about the characters or setting for a story using illustrations and titles.
Retell story events in sequence.
Ask and answer questions about the important characters, settings, and events.
Participate (e.g., react, speculate, join in, read along) when predictably patterned selections of fiction and poetry are read aloud.
Make predictions about what will happen next in a story and explain why the predictions were or were not confirmed.
Sequence a series of events in a literary selection heard or read.
Identify major and minor characters in several stories.
Identify cause and effect of specific events in a biography.
Identify chapter titles and illustrations as parts of a text that help the reader predict what will happen next in a story.
Recognize dialect in conversational voices in stories when they are read aloud.
Form questions about a text and locate facts/details to answer those questions.
Use story details and prior knowledge to understand ideas that are not directly stated in the text.
Connections
Identify similarities and differences between the characters or events in stories by the same author (e.g., The Little Bear stories by Elsa Minarik).
Identify similarities and differences in the works of an illustrator or an author.
Make relevant connections (e.g., relationships, cause/effect, comparisons) between earlier events and later events in text.
Compare (and contrast) literary elements (plots, settings, and characters) across stories.
Identify similarities and differences between the characters or events in a story and the experiences in an author's life (e.g., Laura Ingalls Wilder and the Little House books).
Relate the events and characters in a literary work to information about its setting (e.g., The Remarkable Journey of Prince Jen and information about China's T'ang dynasty).
Analyze the relevance of the setting (e.g., time, place, and situation) to the mood and tone of the text.
Relate the elements of a literary work to the elements of other literary works set in the same historical period.
Analyze the literary techniques used by authors of fiction, poetry, or drama in the same historical period.
Relate a literary work to artifacts, artistic creations, or historical sites of the period of its setting.
Relate a literary work to the artistic and musical masterpieces of the period in which it was written.
Relate a literary work to primary source documents of its literary period or historical setting or to the seminal ideas of its time.
Relate literary works and their authors to the seminal ideas of their time.
Relate literary works and their authors to the political events and seminal ideas of their eras (e.g., Victor Hugo's Les Miserables).
Genre
Identify differences between fiction and nonfiction and determine whether a literary selection is realistic or a fantasy.
Identify differences among the common forms of literature: poetry, drama, fiction, and nonfiction.
Identify common forms of literature (poetry, prose, fiction, nonfiction, and drama) using knowledge of their structural elements.
Distinguish among common forms of literature (poetry, prose, fiction, nonfiction, and drama) using knowledge of their structural elements.
Apply knowledge of different forms of literature as a strategy for reading and writing.
Identify and analyze the characteristics of various genres (poetry, fiction, nonfiction, short story, dramatic literature) as forms with distinct characteristics and purposes.
Identify the characteristics of different forms of prose (short story, novel, novella, essay).
Identify various genres of fiction (e.g., mysteries, science fiction, historical fiction, adventures, fantasies, fables, myths) based on their characteristics.
Identify and analyze how the different genres (e.g., poetry, short story, biography, drama) used by one particular author accomplish different aesthetic purposes.

Compare (and contrast) works with similar themes in two different literary genres, using their structural features as the basis for the comparison (e.g., Frederick Douglass's eulogy of Lincoln and Walt Whitman's poem "O Captain, My Captain").
Explain how the genre for texts with similar themes shapes the meaning.
Compare (and contrast) works within a creative genre that deal with similar themes (e.g., compares two short stories or two novels).

Analyze characteristics of subgenres (e.g., satire, parody, allegory) that overlap or cut across the lines of genre classifications such as poetry, novel, drama, short story, essay, or editorial (e.g., Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels and A Modest Proposal).
Theme
Relate a theme in fiction to life experiences.
Identify the meaning of a favorite poem or story.
Identify themes as moral lessons in folktales and fables.
Compare the moral lessons of several fables.
Identify the theme (moral, lesson, meaning, message, view or comment on life) of a literary selection.
Apply knowledge that theme, whether stated or implied, refers to the basic meaning of a literary text.
Recognize multiple themes in a text and supply evidence from the selection.
Compare (and contrast) similar themes across a variety of selections, distinguishing theme from topic.
Compare (and contrast) classic works of literature that deal with similar topics and problems (e.g., individual and society, freedom and responsibility).
Analyze the way in which the theme or meaning of a selection represents a view or comment on life, providing textual evidence for the identified theme.
Apply knowledge of the concept that a text can contain more than one theme.

Analyze and compare texts that express a universal theme (e.g., the incomprehensibility of life's tragedies, the tragic flaw of a hero or heroine), providing textual evidence (e.g., examples, details, quotations) of the identified theme.
Analyze a writer's word choice and imagery and connect them to theme and/or tone and mood, providing evidence from the text to support the analysis.
Fiction
Identify elements of plot, character, and setting in a favorite story.
Describe the characters' traits in a story.
Identify the elements of stories (problem, solution, character, and setting) and analyze how major events lead from problem to solution.
Identify personality traits of characters and the thoughts, words, and actions that reveal their personalities.
Identify who is telling the story or speaking in a poem.
Explain how the plot, setting, or characters influence the events in a story, using evidence from the text.
Describe a character's traits, relationships, and feelings, using evidence from the text (e.g., thoughts, dialogue, actions).
Describe the relationships between major and minor characters; analyze how a character's traits influence that character's actions.
Identify the plot and its components (e.g., main events, conflict, resolution).
Describe incidents that advance plot in a story or novel, explaining how each incident gives rise to the next or foreshadows a future event.
Provide examples of all the aspects of the setting (time, place, situation) in a story or novel.
Analyze plot development (e.g., conflict, rising action, falling action, resolution, subplots, flashbacks, parallel episodes) to determine whether and how conflicts are resolved.
Describe a character based on the thoughts, words, and actions of the character, the narrator's description, and what other characters say and do.
Analyze the ways characters change or interact with others over time and give supporting evidence from the text.
Determine how central characters' qualities influence the resolution of the conflict.
Interpret a character's traits, emotions, or motivations, and provide supporting evidence from a text.
Analyze the influence of setting (e.g., time of day, place, historical period, situation) on the problem and resolution.
Determine a character's traits from what he/she says about himself/herself.
Contrast points of view (e.g., first vs. third, limited vs. omniscient, subjective vs. objective) in a story or poem.
Analyze such elements in fiction as foreshadowing, flashbacks, suspense, and irony.
Explain how narrator's point of view affects tone, characterization, and plot (e.g., Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird or Richard Wright's Native Son).
Analyze how satire works (e.g., in stories, novels, or other genres of fiction by Mark Twain, such as "The War Prayer").
Analyze, evaluate, and apply knowledge of how authors use techniques and elements (mood, characterization, point of view) in fiction for rhetorical and aesthetic purposes to engage the audience.
Explain how irony, tone, mood, style, and "sound" of language are used for specific rhetorical, aesthetic purposes.
Use several critical lenses (Marxist, feminist, biographical) to interpret literary works.
Analyze the effects of different points of view in a collection of short stories illustrating a variety of points of view (e.g., Points of View by James Moffett and Kenneth McElheny).
Poetry
Identify a regular beat and similarities of sounds in words in responding to rhythm and rhyme in poetry.
Identify rhythm, rhyme, assonance, and alliteration in poetry.
Identify the speaker of a poem.
Identify rhyme, rhythm, repetition, similes, and sensory images in poetry.
Recognize the similarities of sounds in words (e.g., onomatopoeia, alliteration, assonance) and rhythmic patterns in a poetry selection.
Identify characteristics and structural elements (e.g., imagery, rhyme, verse, rhythm, meter) of poetry (narrative poem, free verse, lyrical poem, humorous poem).

Respond to and analyze the effects of the sounds in words (alliteration, onomatopoeia, rhyme scheme), form (free verse, couplets), and figurative language (metaphor, simile) to uncover the meaning of a poem.
Respond to and analyze the effects of figurative language (personification, metaphor, simile, hyperbole) and graphics (capital letters) to uncover the meaning of a poem.
Analyze the characteristics and structural elements of a variety of poetic forms (e.g., epic, sonnet, ode, ballad, lyric, narrative poem, free verse, haiku).

Analyze the effects of sound (alliteration, internal rhyme, rhyme scheme), figurative language (personification, metaphor, simile, hyperbole), and graphics (capital letters, line length, word position) on the meaning of a poem.

Identify, respond to, and analyze the effects of sound (alliteration, onomatopoeia, rhyme scheme, consonance, assonance), figurative language (personification, metaphor, simile, hyperbole, symbolism), and dramatic structure.
Identify, respond to, and analyze the effects of the form and dramatic structure of ballads, elegies, sonnets, and heroic couplets.

Explain how meaning is enhanced through various features of poetry including sound (e.g., rhythm, repetition, alliteration, consonance, assonance), structure or prosody (e.g., meter, rhyme scheme), and graphic elements (e.g., line length, punctuation, word position).

Analyze the effectiveness and effect of diction and imagery (controlling images, understatement, overstatement, irony, paradox, allusion, apostrophe, oxymoron, pun, synecdoche, metonymy) in conveying meaning.
Identify, respond to, and analyze the effects of the form and dramatic structure of ballads, elegies, sonnets, heroic couplets, odes, and villanelles.
Drama
Identify the elements of dialogue and use them in informal plays.
Identify and analyze the elements of plot and character as presented through dialogue in scripts that are read, viewed, listened to, or performed.
Identify the structural elements particular to dramatic literature, such as scenes, acts, and a cast of characters.
Analyze the similarities and differences between a narrative text and its dramatic adaptation.
Identify author's use of dialogue and stage directions.
Analyze the similarities and differences in the setting, characters, and plot of a play and a film based on it.
Identify and analyze how two different playwrights achieve characterization through dialogue in their plays.
Identify and analyze types of dramatic literature (e.g., elements and techniques authors use to create a comedy or tragedy).
Describe the functions of playwright, director, technical designer, and actor.
Identify and analyze how dramatic conventions support, interpret, and enhance dramatic text (e.g., dual role of a chorus as advisor to characters as well as informant to the audience).

Identify and analyze how dramatic conventions (monologue, soliloquy, chorus, aside, dramatic irony) support or enhance dramatic text (e.g., analyzes the purpose and effect of soliloquy in Shakespeare's Macbeth or Hamlet).
Demonstrate understanding of various dramatic conventions (dialogue, dramatic irony, character foils, comic relief) by writing and designing an original play.
Analyze the influence of classical Greek drama on modern plays (e.g., Eugene O'Neill's Mourning Becomes Electra, Jean Anouilh's Antigone).
Style and Language
Identify words that the author selects in a literary selection to create a graphic visual experience.
Identify sensory details in literature and spoken language.
Identify sensory words.
Identify sensory details and figurative language in a story or poem.
Identify and draw conclusions about the author's use of sensory details, imagery, and figurative language.
Recognize dialect in conversational voices in American folk tales.
Identify and analyze the importance of shades of meaning in determining word choice in a piece of literature.
Identify and analyze how an author's use of words creates tone and mood.
Draw conclusions about style, mood, tone, and meaning of prose, poetry, and drama based on the author's word choice and use of figurative language.
Identify and analyze patterns of imagery or symbolism in literary selections.
Describe the importance of sentence variety in the overall effectiveness of a literary work.
Analyze the author's use of figurative language, including personification, symbolism, simile, metaphor, hyperbole, allusion, and imagery in a poetry selection.
Evaluate how an author's choice of words advances the theme or purpose of a work.

Interpret figurative language, including imagery, personification, figures of speech, hyperbole, symbolism, allusion, and allegory, with emphasis on how the writer uses language to evoke readers' emotions.
Analyze patterns of imagery or symbolism and connect them to theme and/or tone and mood.
Analyze and compare style and language among significant cross-cultural literary works.
Literary Nonfiction
Identify the differences in point of view between an autobiography and a biography.
Describe the narrative structure of biographies and autobiographies and the themes or central ideas contained within them.
Describe the structural differences among essays, speeches, autobiographies, and biographies.
Identify and describe the logical connectives and transitional devices in several essays (e.g., by Lewis Thomas or Steven Jay Gould).

Analyze word choice (voice, tone, biblical or metaphoric language or imagery) in well-known speeches and political text (e.g., the Gettysburg Address and Martin Luther King's "Letter from Birmingham Jail").

Identify the purpose of a historically important and well-written speech (e.g., one by Franklin Delano Roosevelt or Winston Churchill during World War II) and determine the essential elements that elaborate it.
Analyze the ways in which a narrator's point of view and language affect interpretation (e.g., Ralph Ellison's Invisible Man).
Analyze denotation, connotation, and irony contained within classical essays (e.g., Ralph Waldo Emerson's "The American Scholar or Thoreau's "On Civil Disobedience").

Distinguish the literary qualities of several well-known biographies (e.g., John Adams and Truman by David McCullough) or several well-known speeches (e.g., John F. Kennedy's and Ronald Reagan's inaugural addresses).

Analyze foundational U.S. documents for their historical and literary significance (e.g., the Declaration of Independence, the Federalist Papers, the Preamble to the U.S. Constitution, Abraham Lincoln's "Gettysburg Address," Martin Luther King's "Letter from Birmingham Jail").
Evaluate the literary elements and techniques in several classical essays and historical speeches.

Analyze differences between informal personal essays that reflect more of the author's personal feeling (e.g., those by George Orwell, Erma Bombeck, Russell Baker) and formal impersonal essays that present ideas removed from the personal circumstances prompting them.
Traditional Narrative and Classical Literature
Identify the adventures or exploits of a character type in traditional literature (e.g., the Anansi tales from Africa).
Identify natural events explained in origin myths.
Describe the events in well-known traditional narratives (e.g., Noah and the Ark or David and Goliath).
Identify phenomena explained in origin myths (e.g., Prometheus stole fire from Zeus and gave it to mortals on earth).
Identify significant characters and events in Greek, Roman, and Norse mythology that have influenced English vocabulary (e.g., the names of the days of the week, months, and constellations).
Compare different versions of the same story from different cultures.

Identify common structures in traditional literature (e.g., characters or story elements often come in threes  such as three bears, three sisters, three wishes, or three tasks  or are magic helpers  such as talking animals, fairies, or elves).
Identify stylistic elements such as hyperbole, refrain, and simile in traditional literature.

Identify specific figures, objects, and places in Greek, Roman, and biblical literature that have influenced writers throughout the ages (e.g., Trojan Horse; Labyrinth; Paradise; Garden of Eden; Tree of Knowledge; Solomon's wisdom; the mark of Cain, Adam and Eve).
Identify similarities and differences in mythologies from different cultures (e.g., ideas of afterlife, roles of deities).
Identify the language styles of different characters in literary works.
Identify conventions in epic tales (e.g., the quest, the hero's tasks, special weapons or clothing).
Identify archetypes in classical literature (e.g., journey of a hero, the tragic flaw, banishment from the Garden of Eden).

Analyze the characters, structure, and themes of classical Greek drama and epic poetry (e.g., the conflict between Creon and Antigone in Sophocles' Antigone as a manifestation of the eternal struggle between human and divine law).
Relate the characters, structure, and themes of classical myths, drama, and epic poetry to contemporary novels and film (e.g., Milton's Paradise Lost and the film version The Natural).

Analyze the influence of mythic, traditional, or classical literature on later literature and film (e.g., the archetypal theme of "the fall" from the Old Testament as they read Hawthorne's "Rapaccini's Daughter").

Demonstrate knowledge of 18th- and 19th-century foundational works of American literature, including works by authors such as Emily Dickinson, Frederick Douglass, Ralph Waldo Emerson, Benjamin Franklin, Nathaniel Hawthorne, Herman Melville, Edgar Allan Poe, Henry David Thoreau, and Mark Twain.

Read and interpret world literature drawn from pre-20th-century authors and know many of the important authors and key works from those eras (e.g., Fyodor Dostoyevsky, Jane Austen, Charles Dickens, Leo Tolstoy).

Identify and analyze a variety of literary and nonliterary landmarks in the history and evolution of the English language that served as major sources of influence on later generations of writers (e.g., Beowulf, Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, Shakespeare's plays, selections from the King James Version of the Bible, John Milton's poems, selections from John Locke's Royal Society for the Improvement of the English Language, selections from Addison and Steele's essays and the first novels).

Use adults as resources to answer questions, clarify information, and demonstrate tasks (e.g., looks through a book on trucks provided by the teacher to find one like his dad drives. Asks a parent volunteer, "Can you show me how to write my name?").

Explore a rich variety of objects and materials provided to discover how things work, what things do, and why things happen (e.g., tests a collection of objects set out by the teacher to find out which ones the magnet will pick up. Exclaims with excitement, "Look! There are worms under this rock. How did they get there?").

Use books and other print materials to find information (e.g., says, "That bus with the 'A' on it goes to my grandma's house." Says, "You have to put the pattern blocks here because the sign says so" when another child asks, "Where do these go?").
Generate questions and gather information from several sources in the classroom, school, or public library.

• Use standard bibliographic format to document sources (e.g., MLA, APA, CMS).

• Use standard bibliographic format to document sources (e.g., MLA, APA, CMS).
